title: Fluids - forces on a cube submerged in water

content.question:
Show all your work for each part of the the question. The parts within the question may not have equal weight.

Three small cubes, <math alttext="A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>A</mtext></math>, <math alttext="B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>B</mtext></math> and <math alttext="C" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>C</mtext></math>, are released from rest from the bottom of a tank of liquid of density <math alttext="rho sub 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>ρ</mi><mn>0</mn></msub></mstyle></math>. The cubes have the same volume <math alttext="V sub 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>V</mi><mn>0</mn></msub></mstyle></math>, and the densities of cubes <math alttext="A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>A</mtext></math>, <math alttext="B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>B</mtext></math> and <math alttext="C" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>C</mtext></math> are <math alttext="rho sub A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>ρ</mi><mtext>A</mtext></msub></mstyle></math>, <math alttext="rho sub B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>ρ</mi><mtext>B</mtext></msub></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="rho sub C" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>ρ</mi><mtext>C</mtext></msub></mstyle></math> respectively, where <math alttext="rho sub A is greater than rho sub B, which is greater than rho sub C, which is greater than rho sub 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>ρ</mi><mtext>A</mtext></msub><mo>></mo><msub><mi>ρ</mi><mtext>B</mtext></msub><mo>></mo><msub><mi>ρ</mi><mtext>C</mtext></msub><mo>></mo><msub><mi>ρ</mi><mn>0</mn></msub></mstyle></math>. The forces exerted on cubes <math alttext="A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>A</mtext></math>, <math alttext="B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>B</mtext></math> and <math alttext="C" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>C</mtext></math> by the bottom of the tank are <math alttext="F sub A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>F</mi><mtext>A</mtext></msub></mstyle></math>, <math alttext="F sub B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>F</mi><mtext>B</mtext></msub></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="F sub C" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>F</mi><mtext>C</mtext></msub></mstyle></math> respectively.

(a) Indicate which of the three forces <math alttext="F sub A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>F</mi><mtext>A</mtext></msub></mstyle></math>, <math alttext="F sub B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>F</mi><mtext>B</mtext></msub></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="F sub C" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>F</mi><mtext>C</mtext></msub></mstyle></math> is the greatest.
_____ <math alttext="F sub A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>F</mi><mtext>A</mtext></msub></mstyle></math> is the greatest.
_____ <math alttext="F sub B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>F</mi><mtext>B</mtext></msub></mstyle></math> is the greatest.
_____ <math alttext="F sub C" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>F</mi><mtext>C</mtext></msub></mstyle></math> is the greatest.
Justify your answer qualitatively, beyond referencing equations.

frqParts.text:
Show all your work for each part of the the question. The parts within the question may not have equal weight.

Three small cubes, <math alttext="A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>A</mtext></math>, <math alttext="B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>B</mtext></math> and <math alttext="C" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>C</mtext></math>, are released from rest from the bottom of a tank of liquid of density <math alttext="rho sub 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>ρ</mi><mn>0</mn></msub></mstyle></math>. The cubes have the same volume <math alttext="V sub 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>V</mi><mn>0</mn></msub></mstyle></math>, and the densities of cubes <math alttext="A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>A</mtext></math>, <math alttext="B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>B</mtext></math> and <math alttext="C" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>C</mtext></math> are <math alttext="rho sub A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>ρ</mi><mtext>A</mtext></msub></mstyle></math>, <math alttext="rho sub B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>ρ</mi><mtext>B</mtext></msub></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="rho sub C" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>ρ</mi><mtext>C</mtext></msub></mstyle></math> respectively, where <math alttext="rho sub A is greater than rho sub B, which is greater than rho sub C, which is greater than rho sub 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>ρ</mi><mtext>A</mtext></msub><mo>></mo><msub><mi>ρ</mi><mtext>B</mtext></msub><mo>></mo><msub><mi>ρ</mi><mtext>C</mtext></msub><mo>></mo><msub><mi>ρ</mi><mn>0</mn></msub></mstyle></math>. The forces exerted on cubes <math alttext="A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>A</mtext></math>, <math alttext="B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>B</mtext></math> and <math alttext="C" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>C</mtext></math> by the bottom of the tank are <math alttext="F sub A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>F</mi><mtext>A</mtext></msub></mstyle></math>, <math alttext="F sub B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>F</mi><mtext>B</mtext></msub></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="F sub C" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>F</mi><mtext>C</mtext></msub></mstyle></math> respectively.

(a) Indicate which of the three forces <math alttext="F sub A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>F</mi><mtext>A</mtext></msub></mstyle></math>, <math alttext="F sub B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>F</mi><mtext>B</mtext></msub></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="F sub C" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>F</mi><mtext>C</mtext></msub></mstyle></math> is the greatest.
_____ <math alttext="F sub A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>F</mi><mtext>A</mtext></msub></mstyle></math> is the greatest.
_____ <math alttext="F sub B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>F</mi><mtext>B</mtext></msub></mstyle></math> is the greatest.
_____ <math alttext="F sub C" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>F</mi><mtext>C</mtext></msub></mstyle></math> is the greatest.
Justify your answer qualitatively, beyond referencing equations.

b) Starting with Newton’s second law, derive a general expression for the normal force that the tank exerts on a cube of volume <math alttext="V sub 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>V</mi><mn>0</mn></msub></math> and density <math alttext="rho sub 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>ρ</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></math> while it rests at the bottom of a tank of liquid of density <math alttext="rho sub 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>ρ</mi><mn>0</mn></msub></math>. Express your answer in terms of <math alttext="V sub 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>V</mi><mn>0</mn></msub></math>, <math alttext="rho sub 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>ρ</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></math>, <math alttext="rho sub 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>ρ</mi><mn>0</mn></msub></math>, and physical constants, as appropriate. Begin your derivation by writing a fundamental physics principle or an equation from the reference booklet.
(c) Justify how the expression for the normal force you derived in part (b) is or is not consistent with the claim made in part (a).

skill.text: 3.B: Apply an appropriate law, definition, theoretical relationship, or model to make a claim.
